title: How to Care for a Christmas Cactus
title_html: How to Care for a Christmas Cactus
content:
Give your Christmas Cactus bright but indirect light.  Keep the plant in a well-lit location (like near a window) away from direct sunlight – too much heat and light can stunt growth and burn the leaves. It should also be away from drafts, heat vents, fireplaces or other sources of hot air. [1] 
 
Move an indoors plant outdoors in summer to a shady location. It is best to keep in a normal house temperature range, about 65 to 75°F (18 to 20°C). That being said, cooler night temperatures can be used to initiate blooming. We'll discuss getting it to bloom in the final section.
If it's in a north or east-facing window, you won't have to worry about light. But if it's in a south or west-facing window, diffuse the light with semi-transparent curtains or some other light-diffusing device.
 
 WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus">How to Care for a Christmas Cactus</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Maggie Moran</a>
</div>

<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=maggiemoran#maggiemoran">Maggie Moran</a>. Maggie Moran is a Professional Gardener in Pennsylvania.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">8 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>A beautiful holiday plant (botanically known as <i>Schlumbergera</i> or <i>Zygocactus</i>), the Christmas Cactus unsurprisingly blooms at Christmas and also sometimes around Easter time if cared for properly. A month prior to Christmas you will be able to watch the tips of the leaves beginning to grow. The tips grow darker as each day passes, until a bud forms. At Christmas time, as if by magic, the buds open to a beautiful flower that will add color and warmth to any holiday season.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Choosing_Your_Spot.2C_Soil.2C_and_Set-Up_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Choosing_Your_Spot.2C_Soil.2C_and_Set-Up">Choosing Your Spot, Soil, and Set-Up</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_81a1ae60de" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_81a1ae60de')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give your Christmas Cactus bright but indirect light.</b> Keep the plant in a well-lit location (like near a window) away from direct sunlight – too much heat and light can stunt growth and burn the leaves. It should also be away from drafts, heat vents, fireplaces or other sources of hot air.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Move an indoors plant outdoors in summer to a shady location. It is best to keep in a normal house temperature range, about 65 to 75°F (18 to 20°C). That being said, cooler night temperatures can be used to initiate blooming. We'll discuss getting it to bloom in the final section.</li>
<li>If it's in a north or east-facing window, you won't have to worry about light. But if it's in a south or west-facing window, diffuse the light with semi-transparent curtains or some other light-diffusing device.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-2-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-2-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_c5dedd3cb1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c5dedd3cb1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Provide the plant a source of humidity if you live in a dry environment.</b> Put a tray of water next to the plant so that the water evaporates and provides humidity. Alternatively, you can make a humidity tray by placing the pot on a waterproof saucer that is filled with gravel and halfway filled with water.

<ul>
<li>Make sure to not let the pot touch the water when it is sitting on the gravel; otherwise the pot will wick up water and make it easier for the roots to rot.</li>
<li>50 to 60% humidity is the ultimate goal.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> If your environment is close to that, you should be fine.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_8eb6a44d48" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8eb6a44d48')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a well-draining container and well-draining soil.</b> For the container, some of the cheap nursery planters will work well, and orchid planters (the plastic basket kind) work well also. Pair this planter with a planter that will hold water and allow the basket to fit down into it. Then, place a few medium sized rocks into the bottom so that the basket container will be held about an inch above the bottom. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Use a combination of 3 parts potting soil to one part sand for the potting medium. An alternative is one part potting soil, two parts peat moss or compost, and one part sharp sand or perlite.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Whichever way you go, pour about two inches of room temperature water into the outer container and set the basket container inside. After about twelve hours, pour out any remaining water. Repeat this as often as the plant needs water; it will vary based on your home's condition. Monitor its need with a moisture prod and adjust accordingly.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_9b227fd527" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9b227fd527')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add fertilizer to assist plant growth.</b> Plants that are actively growing should be given a blooming houseplant-type fertilizer. This is best done for a plant that is 2-3 weeks old. Follow the label directions for how much and how often to feed.

<ul>
<li>Fertilizing is important to keep the plant in good condition; the joints are fragile and can break apart if the plant descends into poor health. Generally, it should be fertilized 2-4 times a year with a 20-20-20 feed, but stop feeding about a month before the buds appear (this usually means stopping by the end of October).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
<a name="qz_anchor_1"></a>
<div class="qz_container qz_desktop" id="qz_container_1">
<div class="qz_score">Score<br/><span class="qz_numerator">0</span> / <span class="qz_denominator">0</span>
</div>
<div class="qz_header">
<p>Part 1 Quiz</p>
<p class="qz_question">What percent humidity should you provide for your Christmas cactus?</p>
</div>
<form action="#" class="qz_form" target="_blank">
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_1_0">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_0" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_0">5 to 10 percent</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Definitely not! An environment with 5 to 10 percent humidity is pretty dry. You need to create an environment with more humidity. <span class="qz_addon">Click on another answer to find the right one...</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_1_1">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_1" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_1">25 to 35 percent</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not quite! Your Christmas cactus needs humidity to thrive. However, it needs more than 25 to 35 percent.  <span class="qz_addon">Guess again!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section correct" id="quiz_1_2">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_2" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_2">50 to 60 percent </label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Yes! You need to provide a humid environment for your Christmas cactus, especially if you live in a dry environment. You can do this by putting a tray of water near the plant or placing the pot on a tray filled with gravel and water.  <span class="qz_addon">Read on for another quiz question.</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_1_3">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_3" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_3">80 to 90 percent</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not exactly! 80 to 90 percent is much more humidity than you need. You can decrease the humidity and still have a healthy plant. <span class="qz_addon">Guess again!</span></p>
</div>
</form>
<div class="wh_ad_inner hidden" data-adtargetid="quizad0" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div class="ad_label ad_label_dollar" id="quizad0"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('quizad0'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addQuizAd('quizad0')</script>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Watering_Your_Christmas_Cactus_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Watering_Your_Christmas_Cactus">Watering Your Christmas Cactus</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_e53f89b0ac" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e53f89b0ac')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Water a Christmas Cactus with care.</b> Caring for this plant can be a bit tricky as you need to take care <i>not to overwater or underwater it</i>:

<ul>
<li>A Christmas cactus is a tropical cactus, not a desert cactus. Unlike most desert cacti, this variety cannot tolerate completely dry soil. If the soil gets too dry, the flowers buds will drop, and the plant will wilt. Feel the soil with your fingers; if it feels dry, it's time to water.</li>
<li>Too much watering will cause spots from white rot to appear on the leaves, and the leaves will likely fall off. The soil should be evenly moist for best growth. The rule of thumb is <i>less water is better than too much water.</i>
</li>
<li>When watering, thoroughly water the plant. Before attempting to water the plant again, check to see that the top inch of soil has dried thoroughly first. Mist leaves as well as watering the soil.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_411b332a67" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_411b332a67')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Change your watering schedule seasonally.</b> Water the cactus based on your environment and the time of year. A good method is to water a cactus as follows:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>
<i>Dry climate, outdoors</i>: Water every two to three days when warm and sunny</li>
<li>
<i>Humid, cool or indoors</i>: Water every week</li>
<li>During the fall and winter months, the plants should be watered less frequently in order to promote blooming.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_e8db635510" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e8db635510')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stop watering around October.</b> When October hits, your watering duties are over. You can carefully resume a light watering in November. If it's dry where you live, feel free to place the pot over a tray of moist pebbles. This is all to set up the bloom happening around Christmas.

<ul>
<li>The only other time you should cease watering is after the plant blooms. At this time, cease watering for about 6 weeks to allow the plant to rest. New growth will still appear – and that is when watering should be resumed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-8.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_9c6f474ae3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9c6f474ae3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-8.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Watch out for bud drop.</b> One of the most frustrating things that can happen to Christmas cactus is after the flower buds have developed they drop off the plant. Bud drop can be caused by several different conditions. Usually it's because of over-watering, but it can also be due to a lack of humidity or insufficient light.

<ul>
<li>If this starts happening, water the plant less and add some fertilizer to the pot. Move it to an area away from a hot radiator or vent and try a new spot where it can get a bit more sunlight.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
<a name="qz_anchor_2"></a>
<div class="qz_container qz_desktop" id="qz_container_2">
<div class="qz_score">Score<br/><span class="qz_numerator">0</span> / <span class="qz_denominator">0</span>
</div>
<div class="qz_header">
<p>Part 2 Quiz</p>
<p class="qz_question">How often should you water your Christmas cactus if it is located in a dry climate or outdoors?</p>
</div>
<form action="#" class="qz_form" target="_blank">
<div class="qz_section correct" id="quiz_2_0">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_0" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_0">Every 2 to 3 days. </label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Correct! You need to water your cactus based on the environment and time of year. If you keep you cactus in a dry climate or outdoors, you should water it every 2 to 3 days. <span class="qz_addon">Read on for another quiz question.</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_2_1">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_1" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_1">Every week.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not exactly! You should water your cactus every week if your cactus in a humid, cool, or indoor environment. You need to water it more frequently if the cactus is in a dry climate or outdoors. <span class="qz_addon">Guess again!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_2_2">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_2" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_2">You don't need to water it.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not necessarily! How often you water your Christmas cactus depends on where you live and the time of year.  <span class="qz_addon">Guess again!</span></p>
</div>
</form>
<div class="wh_ad_inner hidden" data-adtargetid="quizad1" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div class="ad_label ad_label_dollar" id="quizad1"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('quizad1'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addQuizAd('quizad1')</script>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Getting_a_Timely_Bloom_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_a_Timely_Bloom">Getting a Timely Bloom</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-9.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_7631b271d6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7631b271d6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-9.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Encourage the flower blooming for the holiday season by lowering the temperature.</b> The key to getting Christmas cactus to flower during the holiday season is proper light exposure, correct temperatures and limited watering. If you manipulate these things yourself, you can time a bloom just how you'd like.

<ul>
<li>Because this plant is thermo-photoperiodic, it will set buds when day length is about equal to night length and when the temperature drops to 50 to 60 degrees F for several weeks. If the temperature drops further, the plant will not bloom.</li>
<li>From September and October, the Christmas Cactus should be kept in a cool room where temperatures will remain around 50-55°F (10-12°C), give or take a few degrees. Don't expose the plant to freezing temperatures. Plants should be blooming for the holidays if cool treatments are started by early November.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-10.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_ef3b6f6201" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ef3b6f6201')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-10.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep the plant in a dark room during the night.</b> During the fall months, the Christmas Cactus should be placed in a spot where it receives indirect, bright light during the daylight hours but total darkness at night – it requires long, uninterrupted dark periods of about 12 hours or more.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Begin the dark treatments in about mid-October to have plants in full bloom by the holidays. Place the plants in a dark area from about 12 or more hours each night for 6-8 weeks or until you see buds forming. A closet or unused bathroom are ideal places.</li>
<li>Be especially careful with watering at this time. Reduce the watering slightly. Do not soak the soil after a dry period; only moisten the top few inches, since buds, flowers and even leaves can fall off if the roots are suddenly saturated.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-11.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_7ca3c0f356" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7ca3c0f356')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-11.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">When you see flower buds forming, increase light and humidity.</b> The "dark ages" are over when your plant starts budding. At this point, you should increase, humidity, light, water (not too much, of course), and the temperature. In other words, continue as you were a few months ago.

<ul>
<li>If the buds form too early, you can lower the temperature to stunt them. When you're ready, up the temperature and they should resume their progress.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
<a name="qz_anchor_4"></a>
<div class="qz_container qz_desktop" id="qz_container_4">
<div class="qz_score">Score<br/><span class="qz_numerator">0</span> / <span class="qz_denominator">0</span>
</div>
<div class="qz_header">
<p>Part 3 Quiz</p>
<p class="qz_question">What should you do if your cactus' buds form too early?</p>
</div>
<form action="#" class="qz_form" target="_blank">
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_4_0">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_4_0" name="quiz_4" type="radio"/><label for="radio_4_0">Increase the humidity.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Nope! Increasing the humidity will encourage the buds' growth rather than stunt them!  <span class="qz_addon">There’s a better option out there!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_4_1">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_4_1" name="quiz_4" type="radio"/><label for="radio_4_1">Place the cactus in a dark room.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Try again! You don't need to place the cactus in a dark room if its buds form too early. You should only do this during the fall months before the buds bloom. <span class="qz_addon">Choose another answer!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section correct" id="quiz_4_2">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_4_2" name="quiz_4" type="radio"/><label for="radio_4_2">Lower the temperature.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Nice! Lowering the temperature will stunt the buds' growth. When you're ready for the buds to open again around the holidays, you can increase the temperature and they should resume their progress. <span class="qz_addon">Read on for another quiz question.</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_4_3">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_4_3" name="quiz_4" type="radio"/><label for="radio_4_3">Move the plant outside.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not exactly! If you live in a cold climate, you don't want to expose your plant to freezing outdoor temperatures. You also don't want to change the light and humidity by moving your plant outdoors. There's an easier way to monitor bud growth while keeping your plant right where it is! <span class="qz_addon">Pick another answer!</span></p>
</div>
</form>
<div class="wh_ad_inner hidden" data-adtargetid="quizad2" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div class="ad_label ad_label_dollar" id="quizad2"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('quizad2'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addQuizAd('quizad2')</script>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Caring_for_Your_Cactus_Post-Bloom_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Caring_for_Your_Cactus_Post-Bloom">Caring for Your Cactus Post-Bloom</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-12.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_f6e01f487d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f6e01f487d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-12.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Prune the Christmas cactus about a month after blooming.</b> This will encourage the plant to branch out, especially after a period of "rest" has been granted. It will not look very pretty after the blossoms have faded. Some people wait until March or so, when new growth begins, to prune the cactus.

<ul>
<li>As mentioned before, cease watering for 30 days post-bloom. When you see new growth forming, you can begin watering again.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-13.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_fa79769fad" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fa79769fad')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-13.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Propagate a Christmas Cactus by cutting off short, Y-shaped sections of the stem.</b> Each section must consist of two or three joined segments. Allow each section to dry for a few hours before pushing them into a 3-inch pot that contains the same potting soil as the parent plant. Plant halfway down the first segment and water sparingly to prevent rot from developing.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Treat the cuttings as mature plants. In about four to six weeks, the cuttings should have rooted and will begin to show some new growth. They grow quickly, and should take in about two or three weeks. You can fertilize after the cutting has grown one new segment.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=148675" href="#/Image:Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-14.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_b99b41c2bd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b99b41c2bd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care for a Christmas Cactus Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-14.jpg/aid148675-v4-728px-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Repot every 2-3 years.</b> Your plant should be fine for a couple of years unless the root system gets diseased or harmed. Apart from this, a new pot is needed when the roots have filled it or when the soil has been officially depleted of nutrients. Most people do this in the spring.

<ul>
<li>When replanting or repotting, use new, fresh soil. It's worth the few extra dollars since it will probably be sitting in that soil for a long time. Your plant is a living thing like you, so it deserves the best.</li>
<li>The best time for repotting is between February and April, about once every three years. Just be sure not to give it a pot that's too big; the Christmas Cactus flowers best when it's pot-bound.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
<a name="qz_anchor_3"></a>
<div class="qz_container qz_desktop" id="qz_container_3">
<div class="qz_score">Score<br/><span class="qz_numerator">0</span> / <span class="qz_denominator">0</span>
</div>
<div class="qz_header">
<p>Part 4 Quiz</p>
<p class="qz_question">When are the best months to repot your cactus?</p>
</div>
<form action="#" class="qz_form" target="_blank">
<div class="qz_section correct" id="quiz_3_0">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_3_0" name="quiz_3" type="radio"/><label for="radio_3_0">February-April</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Yes! Remember, though, that you only need to repot your cactus every 3 years. <span class="qz_addon">Read on for another quiz question.</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_3_1">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_3_1" name="quiz_3" type="radio"/><label for="radio_3_1">May-August</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not quite! Your cactus needs to be watered regularly during the summer months, so it is not a good time to repot it. <span class="qz_addon">There’s a better option out there!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_3_2">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_3_2" name="quiz_3" type="radio"/><label for="radio_3_2">September-December</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not exactly! Your plant will prepare to bloom in the fall and winter months, so you should not try to repot your plant then. <span class="qz_addon">Choose another answer!</span></p>
</div>
</form>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="485400" data-caid="486273" data-cqid="485417" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="2685476" data-verifier_id="41418" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="26">

</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Horticulturist</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">If you are growing the cactus indoors or in a cooler environment, you should water every week.  If growing outdoors or in a humid and hot environment then water every two to three days. You should also water less in the fall and winter.</div>

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I trim my Christmas cactus? It is too big, and it's hard to find a spot for it in the house. </div>

</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="320700" data-caid="321573" data-cqid="320717" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1823882" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="18">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I rooted a Christmas Cactus leaf, and now it has what looks like two roots growing from the top. What does this mean? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You did everything right. These cacti are epiphytes, which means they grow on trees, so their roots show above the ground as well as below. What you are seeing is a good thing as these are roots looking to grab onto something. It will take some time for the cutting to bloom though (probably 2-3 years). </div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">These are called fruits: the plant flowers have fertilized each other...very special when this happens.</div>

</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="130282" data-caid="131155" data-cqid="130299" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="948194" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="19">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What are the dark pink balls that form on the ends of my Christmas cactus?  Do I need to trim them off?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Don't trim them! The pink balls you see forming on the ends of the leaves are buds. These will bloom into beautiful flowers (generally around Christmas and Easter time). </div>

<div class="section quicksummary sticky summary_with_video" id="quick_summary_section">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Quick_Summary">wikiHow Video: How to Care for a Christmas Cactus</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="quicksummary">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright summarysection" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player"><a href="/Video/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus" id="summary_video_link"><img class="m-video content-fill placeholder" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-0-preview.jpg/1000px-nowatermark-Care-for-a-Christmas-Cactus-Step-0-preview.jpg" id="summary_video_poster"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('summary_video_poster')</script><div class="m-video-intro-over" style="visibility:visible"><div class="m-video-play">
<div class="m-video-play-count-triangle"></div> Watch</div></div></a>
</div></div></div>
<script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-17427132d0'));
//]]>
</script>
</div>
<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>Plant your Christmas Cactus in a well-draining nursery planter and fill it with potting soil and sand in a 3:1 ratio. Place a tray of water next to it to create humidity. Set the cactus in bright but indirect light, such as near a window, moving it to a shady spot outside for the summer. Water the dirt and leaves whenever the top inch of soil gets dry, and stop watering in October to get ready for the bloom. Lower the temperature to 50 to 55 °F until the buds form, then increase light, temperature, and humidity for the rest of the bloom. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For tips on how to make sure your Christmas cactus blooms in time for Christmas, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="s-help-wrap" data-type="summarytexthelp">
<span class="s-help-prompt">Did this summary help you?</span><button class="s-help-response" data-finish-prompt="Thank you! <a href='#' class='firststeplink'>Return to the article to learn more...</a>" data-prompt-text="We are so glad to have helped!" data-textarea-prompt="Please describe what was helpful in the video..." data-type="summarytexthelp" data-value="1" type="submit">Yes</button><button class="s-help-response" data-finish-prompt="Sorry the summary wasn't helpful. <a href='#' class='firststeplink'>Return to the article to learn more...</a>" data-prompt-text="Sorry that the video wasn't helpful." data-textarea-prompt="Please tell us what you would have liked to see in the video..." data-type="summarytexthelp" data-value="0" type="submit">No</button><div class="s-help-feedback-wrap">
<textarea class="s-help-textarea"></textarea><input class="s-help-submit button primary" type="button" value="Submit"/>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
<div id="qa_box"></div>
<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Be sure to turn plants at regular intervals while encouraging new growth. Otherwise you will get lush bloom on one side and few if any on the other.</li>
<li>The cactus will only grow to the circumference of its pot. If you want it to get bigger, you have to put it in a wider pot.</li>
<li>Christmas Cactus is a beautiful plant that can bloom year after year; you will want to keep it even after the holidays pass. You can even pass it down through generations.</li>
<li>The blooming instructions are based on having a cold Christmas. If you reside in the Southern Hemisphere, you may have more difficulty finding this plant around Christmas time, and they'll need more controlled conditions in order to bloom during the holidays. You'll probably have better luck getting them to bloom during the coldest months of the year.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>ASPCA animal poison control center shows Christmas cacti as non-toxic to dogs and cats.</li>
<li>Any sudden changes in temperature, light and watering will damage the Christmas Cactus. Drafts and temperature extremes can cause the flower buds to drop from the plant before they have a chance to open. Introduce changes <i>gradually</i>.</li>
<li>The Christmas cactus should never be placed near a door that opens and closes to the outside. Likewise, keep it away from heating ducts or near the fireplace or drafty areas.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<p class="ur_name">Eileen Hauber</p>
<p class="ur_date">Aug 30, 2016</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ur_review_text">
				"Didn't know about root bound plants flowering better. Nor the humidity being good for the plants. One year my<span class="ur_review_more"> family gave me a zygo cactus for my birthday. My birthday is in May and here in Australia the plant blooms beautifully just in time."</span><span class="ur_ellipsis">..." </span><a class="ur_review_show" href="#ur_anchor_full">more</a>
</div>
<div class="ur_rating">

<p class="ur_name">Chelby Wade</p>
<p class="ur_date">Dec 17, 2017</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ur_review_text">
				"I had no idea to prune the plant. I've had my plant for 20 years, it was my grandmother's before she passed. I believe I know why now, thank you!"</span><span class="ur_ellipsis">..." </span><a class="ur_review_show" href="#ur_anchor_full">more</a>
</div>
<div class="ur_rating">

"</span><span class="ur_ellipsis">..." </span><a class="ur_review_show" href="#ur_anchor_full">more</a>

    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Choosing Your Spot, Soil, and Set-Up",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Give your Christmas Cactus bright but indirect light. Keep the plant in a well-lit location (like near a window) away from direct sunlight \u2013 too much heat and light can stunt growth and burn the leaves. It should also be away from drafts, heat vents, fireplaces or other sources of hot air.[1]\nMove an indoors plant outdoors in summer to a shady location. It is best to keep in a normal house temperature range, about 65 to 75\u00b0F (18 to 20\u00b0C). That being said, cooler night temperatures can be used to initiate blooming. We'll discuss getting it to bloom in the final section.\nIf it's in a north or east-facing window, you won't have to worry about light. But if it's in a south or west-facing window, diffuse the light with semi-transparent curtains or some other light-diffusing device."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Provide the plant a source of humidity if you live in a dry environment. Put a tray of water next to the plant so that the water evaporates and provides humidity. Alternatively, you can make a humidity tray by placing the pot on a waterproof saucer that is filled with gravel and halfway filled with water.\n\nMake sure to not let the pot touch the water when it is sitting on the gravel; otherwise the pot will wick up water and make it easier for the roots to rot.\n50 to 60% humidity is the ultimate goal.[2] If your environment is close to that, you should be fine."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use a well-draining container and well-draining soil. For the container, some of the cheap nursery planters will work well, and orchid planters (the plastic basket kind) work well also. Pair this planter with a planter that will hold water and allow the basket to fit down into it. Then, place a few medium sized rocks into the bottom so that the basket container will be held about an inch above the bottom. [3]\nUse a combination of 3 parts potting soil to one part sand for the potting medium. An alternative is one part potting soil, two parts peat moss or compost, and one part sharp sand or perlite.[4] Whichever way you go, pour about two inches of room temperature water into the outer container and set the basket container inside. After about twelve hours, pour out any remaining water. Repeat this as often as the plant needs water; it will vary based on your home's condition. Monitor its need with a moisture prod and adjust accordingly."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add fertilizer to assist plant growth. Plants that are actively growing should be given a blooming houseplant-type fertilizer. This is best done for a plant that is 2-3 weeks old. Follow the label directions for how much and how often to feed.\n\nFertilizing is important to keep the plant in good condition; the joints are fragile and can break apart if the plant descends into poor health. Generally, it should be fertilized 2-4 times a year with a 20-20-20 feed, but stop feeding about a month before the buds appear (this usually means stopping by the end of October)."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Watering Your Christmas Cactus",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Water a Christmas Cactus with care. Caring for this plant can be a bit tricky as you need to take care not to overwater or underwater it:\n\nA Christmas cactus is a tropical cactus, not a desert cactus. Unlike most desert cacti, this variety cannot tolerate completely dry soil. If the soil gets too dry, the flowers buds will drop, and the plant will wilt. Feel the soil with your fingers; if it feels dry, it's time to water.\nToo much watering will cause spots from white rot to appear on the leaves, and the leaves will likely fall off. The soil should be evenly moist for best growth. The rule of thumb is less water is better than too much water.\n\nWhen watering, thoroughly water the plant. Before attempting to water the plant again, check to see that the top inch of soil has dried thoroughly first. Mist leaves as well as watering the soil."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Change your watering schedule seasonally. Water the cactus based on your environment and the time of year. A good method is to water a cactus as follows:[5]\n\nDry climate, outdoors: Water every two to three days when warm and sunny\n\nHumid, cool or indoors: Water every week\nDuring the fall and winter months, the plants should be watered less frequently in order to promote blooming."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Stop watering around October. When October hits, your watering duties are over. You can carefully resume a light watering in November. If it's dry where you live, feel free to place the pot over a tray of moist pebbles. This is all to set up the bloom happening around Christmas.\n\nThe only other time you should cease watering is after the plant blooms. At this time, cease watering for about 6 weeks to allow the plant to rest. New growth will still appear \u2013 and that is when watering should be resumed."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Watch out for bud drop. One of the most frustrating things that can happen to Christmas cactus is after the flower buds have developed they drop off the plant. Bud drop can be caused by several different conditions. Usually it's because of over-watering, but it can also be due to a lack of humidity or insufficient light.\n\nIf this starts happening, water the plant less and add some fertilizer to the pot. Move it to an area away from a hot radiator or vent and try a new spot where it can get a bit more sunlight."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Getting a Timely Bloom",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Encourage the flower blooming for the holiday season by lowering the temperature. The key to getting Christmas cactus to flower during the holiday season is proper light exposure, correct temperatures and limited watering. If you manipulate these things yourself, you can time a bloom just how you'd like.\n\nBecause this plant is thermo-photoperiodic, it will set buds when day length is about equal to night length and when the temperature drops to 50 to 60 degrees F for several weeks. If the temperature drops further, the plant will not bloom.\nFrom September and October, the Christmas Cactus should be kept in a cool room where temperatures will remain around 50-55\u00b0F (10-12\u00b0C), give or take a few degrees. Don't expose the plant to freezing temperatures. Plants should be blooming for the holidays if cool treatments are started by early November."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Keep the plant in a dark room during the night. During the fall months, the Christmas Cactus should be placed in a spot where it receives indirect, bright light during the daylight hours but total darkness at night \u2013 it requires long, uninterrupted dark periods of about 12 hours or more.[6]\nBegin the dark treatments in about mid-October to have plants in full bloom by the holidays. Place the plants in a dark area from about 12 or more hours each night for 6-8 weeks or until you see buds forming. A closet or unused bathroom are ideal places.\nBe especially careful with watering at this time. Reduce the watering slightly. Do not soak the soil after a dry period; only moisten the top few inches, since buds, flowers and even leaves can fall off if the roots are suddenly saturated."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "When you see flower buds forming, increase light and humidity. The \"dark ages\" are over when your plant starts budding. At this point, you should increase, humidity, light, water (not too much, of course), and the temperature. In other words, continue as you were a few months ago.\n\nIf the buds form too early, you can lower the temperature to stunt them. When you're ready, up the temperature and they should resume their progress.[7]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Caring for Your Cactus Post-Bloom",
            "position": 4,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Prune the Christmas cactus about a month after blooming. This will encourage the plant to branch out, especially after a period of \"rest\" has been granted. It will not look very pretty after the blossoms have faded. Some people wait until March or so, when new growth begins, to prune the cactus.\n\nAs mentioned before, cease watering for 30 days post-bloom. When you see new growth forming, you can begin watering again."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Propagate a Christmas Cactus by cutting off short, Y-shaped sections of the stem. Each section must consist of two or three joined segments. Allow each section to dry for a few hours before pushing them into a 3-inch pot that contains the same potting soil as the parent plant. Plant halfway down the first segment and water sparingly to prevent rot from developing.[8]\nTreat the cuttings as mature plants. In about four to six weeks, the cuttings should have rooted and will begin to show some new growth. They grow quickly, and should take in about two or three weeks. You can fertilize after the cutting has grown one new segment."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Repot every 2-3 years. Your plant should be fine for a couple of years unless the root system gets diseased or harmed. Apart from this, a new pot is needed when the roots have filled it or when the soil has been officially depleted of nutrients. Most people do this in the spring.\n\nWhen replanting or repotting, use new, fresh soil. It's worth the few extra dollars since it will probably be sitting in that soil for a long time. Your plant is a living thing like you, so it deserves the best.\nThe best time for repotting is between February and April, about once every three years. Just be sure not to give it a pot that's too big; the Christmas Cactus flowers best when it's pot-bound."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }

content_html:
Give your Christmas Cactus bright but indirect light. Keep the plant in a well-lit location (like near a window) away from direct sunlight – too much heat and light can stunt growth and burn the leaves. It should also be away from drafts, heat vents, fireplaces or other sources of hot air.[1]
  • Move an indoors plant outdoors in summer to a shady location. It is best to keep in a normal house temperature range, about 65 to 75°F (18 to 20°C). That being said, cooler night temperatures can be used to initiate blooming. We'll discuss getting it to bloom in the final section.
  • If it's in a north or east-facing window, you won't have to worry about light. But if it's in a south or west-facing window, diffuse the light with semi-transparent curtains or some other light-diffusing device.
